meanings.definition: To strip of clothing, ornament, or equipment
meanings.sent1: She decided to devest herself of the heavy winter coat.
meanings.sent2: After a long day at work, he eagerly devested his uncomfortable shoes.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick was to devest himself of all his clothes and then make them reappear.
meanings.sent4: The storm threatened to devest the trees of their colorful leaves.
meanings.sent5: The superhero had to devest himself of his cape to move quickly through the narrow alley.

meanings.definition: To divest or strip of possession or rights
meanings.sent1: The king had the power to devest the nobleman of his title and lands.
meanings.sent2: The company decided to devest itself of the unprofitable division.
meanings.sent3: The judge's ruling would devest the defendant of all claims to the inheritance.
meanings.sent4: The new law threatened to devest citizens of their privacy rights.
meanings.sent5: The decision to devest him of his voting rights was met with strong opposition.

meanings.sent1: The wildfire continued to devest the forest, leaving only charred trees behind.
meanings.sent2: The invading army sought to devest the enemy's territory and resources.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous raccoon managed to devest the picnic area of all its food.
meanings.sent4: The economic crisis threatened to devest the small town's businesses.
meanings.sent5: The tornado's path seemed to devest everything in its way, leaving destruction in its wake.
